sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying coil
message_1: A physics student is asked to calculate the magnetic field produced by a circular coil with 20 turns, a radius of 0.05 meters, and a current of 0.5 amps flowing through it. The coil is placed at a point on the axis of the coil with a distance of 0.1 meters from the center. What is the magnitude and direction of the magnetic field at this point?
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field produced by a circular coil at a point on its axis, we can use the formula:

B = (μ₀ * N * I * R²) / (2 * (R² + x²)^(3/2))

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π × 10^(-7) T·m/A), N is the number of turns, I is the current, R is the radius of the coil, and x is the distance from the center of the coil to the point on the axis.

Given the values:
N = 20 turns
I = 0.5 A
R = 0.05 m
x = 0.1 m

We can plug these values into the formula:

B = (4π × 10^(-7) T·m/A * 20 * 0.5 A * (0.05 m)²) / (2 * ((0.05 m)² + (0.1 m)²)^(3/2))

B = (4π × 10^(-7) * 20 * 0.5 * 0.0025) / (2 * (0.0025 + 0.01)^(3/2))

B ≈ (1.2566 × 10^(-5) * 20 * 0.5 * 0.0025) / (2 * (0.0125)^(3/2))

B ≈ (6.283 × 10^(-7)) / (2 * 0.0277)

B ≈ 1.134 × 10^(-5) T

The magnitude of the magnetic field at the point is approximately 1.134 × 10^(-5) Tesla.

The direction of the magnetic field produced by the circular coil is along the axis of the coil. Since the current flows in a circular path, we can use the right-hand rule to determine the direction of the magnetic field. If you curl the fingers of your right hand in the direction of the current, your thumb will point in the direction of the magnetic field. In this case, the magnetic field will be pointing either into or out of the plane of the coil, depending on the direction of the current.
